PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

 

Debate on the Address

 

(Third Allotted Day)

 

 

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [25th May, 2009],

 

     'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:–

 

     "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of

Column: 419

the Government at the Opening of the Second Session of this Parliament.".' – [Mr Michael Palmer].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join the debate.  Sir, much has been said about the unprecedented circumstances that we are now in today and how we should turn adversities into opportunities as we close our ranks, build up our resilience, ride out this crisis and emerge a stronger people. Indeed we have overcome many crises in our short history and each time the interval between crises seems shorter.

 

     Certainly, those who appreciate and take up the opportunities and face the challenges head on will succeed. However, the implication is that there will be those who will be left behind, widening our income gap. To many of those in this latter group, it may not be due to the lack of motivation but perhaps the lack of understanding of the new realities and challenges that the President had spelt about. What they constantly hear, probably, is the need for them to upgrade, get retrained and acquire new skills.

 

     But, Sir, for someone who is a sole breadwinner – perhaps just earning $1,200 a month – supporting a spouse and four school-going children and faced with reduced income due to cost cutting measures of his employer, his immediate worry is certainly how to supplement his income to ensure his family’s survival, not upgrading or retraining. We hear much of how our extensive social safety net has been developed to meet the needs of such a family. His family will probably be saved by the safety net this time round. His children will benefit from MOE’s increased funding, being able to go to school, receiving support for their meals, pocket money, transportation, etc. He may be

Column: 420

assisted with another HDB loan to downgrade to a smaller flat to right size the housing loan that he may be able to afford with his reduced income.

 

     However, given the shorter interval between economic crises, will this head of household be prepared for the next downturn? Or will it take another perhaps even wider and deeper safety net to be spread for this family at that time? What would this family have learnt from this downturn that will better prepare them for the next? Perhaps, the need to manage expenses better for financial prudence? Or the importance of investing in the young and prioritise household expenditure to reflect this? Or the importance for constant upgrading and finding new niche areas to ensure longer term employability?

 

     Sir, in the last decade alone, we have been confronted with three major crises – the economic downturn following 911 in 2001, SARS in 2003 and now, the global financial crisis. But have we systematically assessed what have we, as a society, learnt to ensure that we are always better prepared for each subsequent downturn. What have Singaporeans learnt about household financial planning during the previous downturns to ensure that they are more prepared for this and subsequent downturns? Sir, we have said repeatedly that we have grown stronger after every crisis and we will do so again this time round.

 

     Sir, it has been said that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. With individual households reflecting and identifying their learning points, collectively as a society, we will be able to see better what we have gained from this crisis.  This, in essence, is building up our individual and societal resilience. My fear is that if we do not consciously go through this process of reflection, we may lose the opportunity and be faced with the next crisis having to reinvent the wheel – expanding our social safety net,

Column: 421

asking Singaporeans to retrain, etc. Similarly, the Government and related agencies should also reflect on the learning points in terms of how the current policies implemented previously have met their objectives – for example, in encouraging self reliance, increasing resilience in the people through programmes like Work Support and Work Income Supplement (WIS).

 

     Sir, one clear key learning point from this crisis is for us to ensure we have savings for a rainy day. Today, we see the value of this in the Government’s ability to use its reserves (or savings) to support Singaporeans to ride through this severe economic storm. Can we translate this learning point to encourage Singaporeans to save more for future economic storms that may hit us? Can the Government facilitate through financial incentives for Singaporeans to save more?

 

     Sir, we know that apart from our compulsory savings through the CPF, Singaporeans’ rate of personal savings is low. We are able to achieve a record 90% home ownership rate because of our compulsory savings. Thus, can we use this national savings infrastructure to encourage further savings by Singaporeans? While the CPF mechanism was designed to ensure Singaporeans have sufficient savings for old age, can we start thinking how we can capitalise on the mechanism to help Singaporeans save for rainy days, given the frequency and shorter intervals between rainy days. Today, the individual member’s CPF account consists of the Ordinary Account, Medisave Account and Special Account. Can we consider creating another account, say, the Economic Downturn (ED) Account, within the individual member’s CPF account? We can allow members to withdraw this part of their savings during an economic downturn.

 

     To ensure that we do not compromise the current system of savings for

Column: 422

retirement, the monthly CPF contribution will have to be increased, to be channeled into this account. However, the Government may ensure buy-in from Singaporeans for such a scheme by offering attractive interest rates to this account as it did in the recent move to offer an additional 1% to the interest rate of the first $60,000 of the members’ combined CPF savings. Further sweeteners can come in the form of CPF top-ups that Government may give during good years and channelled to this account with more going to the lower income group to incentivise them further.

    

     Sir, I know how the Government religiously protects the CPF system and it should be rightly so. What I am proposing is to ride on the current infrastructure in the CPF system as well as Government’s already existing method of redistributing wealth to Singaporeans, to prepare for the next downturn. Indeed, when we are faced with an economic downturn, we constantly hear calls by Singaporeans to allow them to use their CPF savings to buffer the crisis. “It is my money,” they say. This proposal serves to meet this sense of personal security that Singaporeans want to have in riding out an economic downturn.

 

     Sir, I am confident that when the next downturn comes, the Government will continue to help Singaporeans ride it with enhanced social safety nets. The proposal of an ED account can supplement Singaporeans’ enhanced self reliance, confidence and esteem as they will have their own savings to buffer the downturn.

 

     Learning point number 2 – the family and the next generation. Sir, as part of the reflection process on learning from this downturn, I urge that we systematically study the groups of Singaporeans that are most severely affected by the downturn. We know that no one is spared – not even the PMETs. We also know that in an economic

Column: 423

downturn, reduced household income becomes the order of the day. However, lower income, coupled with larger family size, makes the family even more vulnerable to falling into severe crisis during a downturn. The approach as laid out in the President’s speech and the various Ministries’ addenda is right – invest in the children and secure a better future for the next generation.

 

     However, I think it is time that we studied further, from the experience of this downturn, the profile of families who are more vulnerable. There will be a group who might have been eligible for the HOPE scheme but chose not to join the scheme. MCYS should continue to reach out to this group to strengthen their coping capacities and minimise their risks of being severely affected by the next downturn. But there may be another group who may not have been eligible for HOPE currently. For example, HOPE is currently extended to couples who possess post-secondary education. Applicants with post-secondary education must not earn more than $1,000 to qualify for HOPE and the household income must not be more than $1,500 a month.  This may be the group whom we feel will be able to manage and cope and have more children.

 

     Can we study the profile of those affected by the downturn to ascertain their level of vulnerability and perhaps begin to relook at the eligibility criteria for HOPE? I am not suggesting that we expand HOPE to those with more than two children. We should keep the principle of families on HOPE to keep their families small so that they can focus their resources on providing their children with a stable and supportive environment. But I what I am suggesting is to consider extend HOPE to families who may be more vulnerable today and tomorrow –

Column: 424

the group that we thought were not as vulnerable previously – so that they will be able to keep their families small and not have to struggle as much and be better able to cope when the next and subsequent crises come.

 

     Sir, I would like to continue speaking on the next learning point, specific to the Malay-Muslim community.  Learning point number 3 – the Malay community, strengthening families through community efforts. Please allow me to continue my speech in Malay.

 

     (In Malay):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  Mr Speaker, the economic downturn that we are facing today has highlighted a few pertinent issues for the Malay/Muslim community. President Nathan in his Address has outlined the Government’s plan to ensure that our nation can overcome this downturn and continue progressing in a new era that is said to be uncertain. We often come across news about many workers, including Malay workers, who are directly affected by retrenchments. Just imagine the knock-on effects towards their families.

 

     Sir, this is not the first time that we face economic difficulties, but the time may have come for our community to begin pondering on what we should do to ensure that we are more prepared to face the next downturn.

 

     I would like to focus my speech on the aspect of family development – an institution that is important as a pillar to ensure our community’s progress. We are often reminded about the issues of dysfunctional or problematic families that continue to burden our community. The problems faced by these families are very complex, and will become more complicated as they face this economic downturn, because they usually have many family members. What should and can we do?

 

Column: 425

     I feel that an important issue is to help high-risk families by providing them the skills to outline their family’s vision. What do they want for their own families after 20 years of marriage? Where can they see achievements in their careers? Have their job skills improved and thus increased their pay scale as well as their family’s source of income? Where do they see their children going to? Is it to a post-secondary institute or the university? Have they planned or will plan to provide early schooling to strengthen their children basic education?

 

     Are family income, intellectual capability and skills enough to ensure that they can achieve this vision? If not, what can they do? If necessary, how can they balance the process of planning for the family with the resources they possess, to ensure that they can give sufficient attention to guide their children and develop their families?

 

     These basic questions must be presented to the Malay/Muslim community so that we can together ensure stronger and more confident Malay/Muslim families, and that we can create a new generation that is successful and contributes to the nation.

 

     Sir, the second issue is related to divorce matters, reconstituted families and the community’s role in this. I have, on a few occasions, highlighted the issue of divorce and remarriages, and its effects, before this House. Often, we find that the direct consequence of divorce is the failure of fathers to give maintenance to the children after their divorce. What complicates the problem is that the father made a decision to remarry, even though he still fails to give maintenance to the children from his first marriage. This failure to do so often continues after he marries again.

 

     Mr Speaker, we are aware that even though they have divorced from their

Column: 426

partners, they are still fathers, still accountable, and must continue to provide maintenance to these children. Their role as mentors, advisers and observers should continue after divorce. Unfortunately, we find that the main reason for dysfunctional families is when these men fail to continue their roles as fathers and leaders to their children.

 

     More importantly, what is the role of the community to ensure that our men are compelled to exercise their responsibility?  If they fail to provide maintenance and special attention to their children – but they still want to remarry with the possibility of continuing to neglect their responsibilities – what then is the community’s response to them? Should the community encourage them to continue their plans to remarry? Or should we remind them of their incapability to play the roles as fathers to the children from their first marriage? I hope that this issue that I highlighted will be the starting point for the Malay/Muslim community to analyse the role of men in the social problems of our community. Also important is the role of the community members to become the catalyst that can increase the awareness of men towards their responsibilities.


*Cols. 531-534.

 

 

     (In English): Sir, I came to this House in 2001 and then we were faced with the economic downturn as a result of the 911 attacks and its effects.  Then, at the community level, I went through my first initiation into the world of Chinese songs.  I was asked to lead in a song that was aimed to inspire my residents – the song "Ming tien hui geng hao" or "Tomorrow will be better".  I shall not attempt to sing the song today but allow me to share the English translation of the chorus for fear that I would forget the Chinese lyrics.  It reads:

 

     "Sing with passion and stretch out our hands
     Let us embrace our dreams

Column: 427

     Let us come together with sincerity
     Let us smile with pride
     Let us look forward to a better tomorrow".

 

     I believe this song will continue to be relevant now and as we face subsequent downturns, we must believe that the next day can and will be better. Even more so, if we reflect on our experiences today, learn from it, work together with our hearts and minds, the people and the Government, towards a common dream and a common destiny.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, "ming tien yi ding hui geng hao".  I support the motion.

 

1.47 pm

 

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, Singapore's destiny is tied to the destiny of the big countries because of its small size.  Singapore is like a sampan, floating in the sea.  When the tide comes up, the sampan will rise, and when the tide goes out, the sampan will sink with the ebbing tide.  This makes Singapore vulnerable to what is happening in the world.  Singapore must always be alert and be on its toes for the tide can suddenly change and good opportunities come our way and we can reap the investments that are available.  Singapore, therefore, must maintain a good infrastructure, governed by a strong and efficient democratic government, checked by a strong Opposition.  It will make sure that the Government not be allowed to degenerate into an authoritarian one. 

 

     The political system must be changed to give maximum representation that will strengthen our society and our lives.  The present GRC system must be abolished.  If it is not possible, then it must be modified by its present size of five or six to two-member GRCs, comprising one ethnic Member and one Chinese Member,

Column: 428

and the two-member GRCs be limited to 20.  Going by the present number of parliamentary seats, there are 40 single-seat constituencies now.  Bigger GRCs are not needed because a two-member GRC can produce the optimal number of the minority race MPs while maximising meritocracy in Singapore's electoral system. 

 

     There must be free and plausible media where more news of the Opposition is allowed.  This also includes activities of the two incumbent Opposition MPs.  The views of the Opposition must be heard by the public.  This is in line with the changed world.  America has, for the first time, elected a black-African American to be its President.  Political system must evolve with the times. 

 

     To meet the challenges of India and China, to protect ourselves against protectionism, Singapore must take concerted efforts to embrace Malaysia.  We must aim to have an economic union with Malaysia.  With a total population of about 27 million between the two countries, we can build an internal market of our own.  This, to a certain extent, enables us to fight protectionism.  

 

     In his speech, the President said, amongst other things, "we must have social cohesion".  Social cohesion is about arousing the emotions of people to feel a sense of togetherness, unity and closeness, but Government policies do not reflect this, especially in regard to Opposition MPs.  We practise one country, two-system policy in regard to CIPC funding for community works and no proper amenities to all the MPs although they are legitimately elected. 

 

     Lastly, in order to have gracious living, we must inculcate good values to our young ones by teaching them to have humility, compassion and kindness.

Column: 429

 

1.52 pm

 

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Mr  Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on the motion.

 

     Sir, speaking only two months after the Budget Statement, speaks volumes about how an extraordinary budget for extraordinary times, can be quite extraordinary.  One might ask, why the need to prorogue Parliament.  Uniquely Singapore, perhaps?  But more than that, Sir, it is an important signal about the continuing challenges that we have to face in these very unpredictable times. 

 

     We have always been challenged by all kinds of problems and issues, from self-government, which we celebrate its 50th anniversary this June, to independence pangs, communism, racial and religious extremism, regional and international relations, and, of course, economic slowdown, to meltdown and the vagaries of economic development.  Some speak of recovery  in the U-shape, some the V-shape, but what the President asks for is that no matter what, we Singaporeans have to remain in the G-shape, in good shape,  physically and psychologically, to face the continuing challenges.  After all, we are in the midst of unpredictable times.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the President spoke of the roller-coaster ride over the last three years.  But I wonder whether how many in this House have really taken a roller-coaster. Some are so huge that the sight of them alone can be very scary.  For example, The Six Flags in Jacksonville in the US.  Some believe that the US, the world's largest economy, was the cause of this recession and its U- or V-shaped recovery  will very much depend on  how the Americans tackle their problems.  Meanwhile, as the President said, we cannot sit around wringing hands but instead should get our mind and body prepared for the opportunities that will

Column: 430

present themselves when the situation turns.  If I may add, judging from the debate yesterday in Parliament, even the soul, when we discuss the kind of secularism we want for future Singapore.  Here, I would like to thank Prof. Thio for remembering minor mortals like me when she eloquently presented her case about secularism with a soul in Singapore.

 

     May I, Sir, focus on  three areas raised by the President: (1) the new challenging world environment; (2) enhancing our economic competitiveness; and (3) evolving our political system.  

 

     The President's observation that the re-drawn global landscape will be less benign and predictable is worth paying attention to.  With growing globalisation, and emerging economies like China and India, we need to continue to remain nimble and competitive.  While China and India will draw lots of attention, we must also ensure that we can take the other opportunities that are presenting themselves.  By some coincidence, during the break after President's Address, the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Dato' Sri Najib Tun Razak and the Amir of Qatar made official visits to Singapore.  This serves to remind us that there are other opportunities which we should actually do a lot more in terms of the steps that we need to take to prepare for. 

 

     I think we all know about the Middle East.  We have been going there quite often with many delegations by the Prime Minister, Senior Minister Goh, Minister Mentor and many other Ministers.  But Middle East is not an easy area.  As opportunities get more difficult and more competitive, I think we must also ensure that we do not lose out in our race for the benefits in Middle East. 

 

     Similarly, with Malaysia, if I may cite what happened during lunch when Dato' Najib visited the Sultan Mosque.  On the advice that Dato' Sri Najib wanted food which is non-oily, so somebody had

Column: 431

ordered Italian food for him.  And, mind you, that was Friday and having lunch at Arab Street.  So, when the waitress went round to Dato' Najib asking him what would he like – chicken pasta or seafood pasta – he gave a smile and said, "Briyani, please."  And that is the kind of local reaction, being a Friday, having lunch at Arab Street, I thought briyani or murtabak would have been the answer.  But being Singapore, we immediately reacted to it and within five to 10 minutes, we had briyani and murtabak on the table.  I do not know whether we can call it "murtabak diplomacy", but I think we need to be attuned to the kind of needs that we have when we meet and look for opportunities with our neighbours, especially Malaysia and Indonesia. 

 

     The Amir of Qatar had a very short visit and he told us that, in fact, he had to rush back to Doha because President Abbas of Palestine was visiting him and also the Prime Minister of China, Mr Wen Jiabao.  Now, this again reminds us that, in fact, when it comes to Middle East, they have so many suitors and if we are not nimble enough, and if we are not up to speed, I think we will also lose out in the race. 

 

     Sir, on the second point about being competitive, may I just relate my experience as Mayor of North-East CDC.  When I was first appointed as Mayor of North-East CDC, it was basically with a task to promote social bonding.  But before we knew it, economy started to slow down and we had to be told that, in fact, the CDCs now have to pay a lot of attention to jobs, jobs, jobs.   To me, that is even more significant because what is bonding when you have your neighbours with empty stomachs?  So, this experience of converting the CDCs to doing a lot more in terms of providing financial assistance and job assistance had made 

Column: 432

the CDCs a lot more meaningful.  In the process, we are also encouraging our residents, our Singaporeans, that while we provide assistance, it is only in the interim, and the more important aspect of assistance is actually to provide them with the right skills, right training and re-training and

 

 

that will promise them a longer term solution to their predicament.  In that way, they do not have to actually continue to be dependent on dole-outs and financial assistance for a long time, and they can live with true dignity.

 

     So, from jobs and bonding, what I call "JAB", we move on to "JELL" – jobs, employability and lifelong learning.  We have seen, how, in fact, the CDCs have matured and played a more important role.  On that note, I would like to urge the Government to give due consideration as to what kind of resources that we need to provide to the CDCs.  The CDCs are now reaching out to more of the grassroots organisations and their advisors, and I think they need more resources to be able to bring about the kind of bonding and outreach that is needed on the ground.  The CDCs are well placed in terms of understanding the ground better than most of the Ministries and the CDCs should be given the kind of resources they deserve.

 

     On the final point, Sir, yes, I agree with the President that our political system is not set in stone.  Change we must, and indeed we have made the changes, for example, the NCMP, the NMP and the GRC system.  While we want to be true to the needs of change and times, I think we must change slowly for we do not want to lose the very fundamentals why we introduce GRCs, for example.  GRCs have been able to produce the kind of inclusive participation, very multi-racial in its outlook and approach, and I think this has made the minority communities feel very much included in the whole political system of Singapore.  Change we must, but change

Column: 433

we must not bring about a divisive political climate.  We must remain inclusive and we must promote harmony. 

 

     On that note, Sir, allow me to continue, briefly, in Malay.

 

     (In Malay): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A*.]Our political system, Mr Speaker, as the President has said, is not cast in stone. Will there still be a future for their children and their future generation? Column: 435

     Much has been said of the strategies that the Government has adopted in ensuring our future economic well-being. There are broadly two approaches to this, and I will call it the "High" and the "Low" level approaches.

This however, Sir, should not deter us from continuing to look for good companies to take significant stakes, particularly if we decide that holding it for the longer term would give us better returns on our money.

Now, let me explain. The Government has regularly stated that as a sovereign wealth fund investor, it is in most cases a passive investor. In many of its investments, the Government does not ask for board representation, but would be happy to keep its substantial shareholder status while leaving the company to the care of the managers. This is a pity really. We could have used our significant share advantage to provide training and exposure opportunities to Singaporeans.

 

     One of the many challenges of being a small country is the lack of opportunity for Singaporeans to find the opportunity to compete on the world stage. We are

Column: 436

talking about exposure to corporate planning and decision making at a higher level and in a completely different cultural environment. Few Singaporeans make it to this realm of seniority, and to those who make it are often celebrated as local heroes.  Allowing more Singaporeans to participate at such senior levels, and I should add, not necessarily as employees but even as interns as well, would give more Singaporeans the occasion to build up their confidence and their capabilities and, in the longer term, bring our managerial skill-sets to international blue chip standards. It is often said, and I believe this to be true, that Singaporeans are, by and large, well educated and bright. However, their vision of the world is often constrained in the same manner as the proverbial frog that sees the world from the depth of the well. Given the right opportunity and environment, I am sure we will find more Singaporeans taking their companies from being third rate to first.


     Our significant stake in foreign companies may also be used to provide opportunities for our small and medium enterprises to work with these companies.  As with managers, our entrepreneurs do not have the opportunity or the know-how to partner with these enterprises to grow their businesses.  However, if our Government can be a trail blazer, a path may be opened up for them to confidently take the plunge by going into new areas with foreign partners who can now guide and work with them.

 

     As a simple illustration, a significant investment in, say, a pharmaceutical company should help to open the way to local companies that provide laboratory services to work with these companies. The support need not be confined to the operations of the pharmaceutical company in Singapore alone, but any where else in the world where our local laboratory can effectively and competitively set up presence and provide the service. This

Column: 437

would yet be another way that we can provide opportunities for local industries to grow. Additionally, opportunities may also be opened up for collaboration in areas such as joint marketing, research and development. Singapore provides a strong educational foundation for its people. With an anticipated 30% of the student cohort going into tertiary education, there would be sufficient talent for local enterprises to engage in more research and development and to work with foreign multi-national companies to advance the frontiers of knowledge. Again, leveraging on our Government’s investments overseas, we would be able to use these investments to help local SMEs to ride on the bandwagon of world-class companies to succeed in the international arena. I often wondered if Creative Technology had had the benefit of working with a company like Apple in the area of branding and value proposition, the battle for MP3 might have had a different outcome.
 

     There is, therefore, a recognisable need for our Government when investing its sovereign wealth fund to consider a broader canvass beyond returns on investment and look at how it can further enhance its strategic value by using it to benefit the Singaporean managers and enterprises.

 

     Going beyond, the Government can assist local enterprises further by deepening the partnership with the SMEs in its overseas ventures.  To be sure, the Government is already doing this through IE Singapore, A*STAR, and SPRING Singapore, and the like.  However, the question is whether more can be done and in what areas.  Sir, I believe more can be done, and in certain key strategic areas. I shall name two for now.

Column: 438

America, Eastern Europe and Africa, to name a few. These are new markets that will present new and exciting opportunities for our local entrepreneurs to do business. Just the other day, I was having a conversation with Olivia Lum of Hyflux. She told me that although the general economic climate has not improved very much, she is, however, receiving steady and strong orders from Africa where Hyflux also operates. These are orders from countries that have natural resources, particularly oil, and are prepared to spend to improve its infrastructure during this time.  I do believe that our Government tries to bring local businesses along with them when a Minister makes official trips overseas. It is, however, one thing to bring them along to make a casual introduction, and another to work with local businesses on how they can effectively seal relationships with local businessmen to ensure the smooth passage of investment in these foreign territories. How far should IE Singapore go in providing assistance to the SMEs in finding the right foreign partner?  We know that, with a strong local partner, the chances of succeeding in a foreign venture would be that much higher.

 

     Secondly, as we move into a higher economic gear, we can no longer rely on traditional manufacturing to ensure our long-term survival. Knowledge and intellectual property are going to be the key to ensure that we can continue to charge a premium for our goods and services and to enable us to stay competitive. The Americans have been leading on research and like them, we must leverage on technology to remain competitive. However, as a small country with a small population base, we must be realistic about our ability to come up with original and inventive ideas. What we cannot achieve by sheer ingenuity and ability of our population, we can achieve by looking to the world to acquire these rights.  Presently, the Government has

Column: 439

done much to provide the incentives and encouragement to our local innovators to not only register their patents but also to help take these patents from being ideas to commercial exploitation. On the other hand, there is more that the Government can do.  For example, the Government can help local enterprises by working with them to discover intellectual property rights elsewhere and partnering these enterprises to acquire and own these rights or securing a longer term licence that will enable them to fully exploit these patents commercially.  In doing so, the SMEs can widen the intellectual property pool that they can use to increase their chances of success. 

 

     Sir, we constantly bemoan the fact that we do not have land and resources to meet even the most basic of our needs.

 

 

In today’s globalised economy, the lack of resources in Singapore need not be a limiting factor.  We should exploit opportunities for resource ownership elsewhere to help expand and improve on our capacities. Intellectual property rights that I just mentioned are but one example. Land is another.  Just think of the possibilities that acquiring more land overseas will do to our relative insecurity over food supply.  If our Government could provide funding and create opportunities for Singapore SMEs to own and operate farms overseas on a big scale and use these farms to channel their produce specifically to the Singapore market, it will give Singaporeans the much needed assurance of a constant supply of food, particularly in view of the recent experience of the relative lack of supply of rice following the sharp price increases.


     Economic progress and prosperity will not mean much to our country if we are not able to maintain our social cohesion. That ours is a fragile democracy of many interest groups is a constant reminder to all of us to be mindful of the need to

Column: 440

preserve our national unity through civil discourse and mutual respect of views, even if those are not necessarily shared by all. More importantly, our social cohesion must also be founded on the key values that our society has come to embrace; values that define who we are and what we stand for as a people.


     The recent incident involving the takeover of AWARE by a group of concerned Singaporeans demonstrates just how fragile our society is. For a brief period of time, our nation was on the boil. What turned out to be a relatively simple and lawful act of democracy suddenly turned into a deeply polarised and heated debate between the Christian Right and the homosexual and lesbian interest groups.  The spotlight was quick to focus on a few key groups, rightly or wrongly – namely, the Church, as seen to be represented by the supposed usurpers; the old leadership who were seen to champion the rights of the homosexuals and the lesbians in Singapore; the Ministry of Education who denied knowledge of the instructor’s manual on Comprehensive Sexual Education (CSE) in schools run by AWARE; and, of course, the press.


     Sir, I do not intend to go into the rights and wrongs of the way in which a group of concerned ladies decided to take over the leadership of a voluntary welfare organisation, save to say that I find it odd that democracy suddenly takes on a very different meaning when a group of new members decide to legitimately contest in an election to determine a new agenda. I also find it odd that many of the members who did not bother even to attend the most important meeting in the year to elect a new leadership should now decide to raise a howl of protest after the event.  If they, meaning the old members, were that concerned in the first place, I believe they should have taken a more active role in the affairs of the organisation.  Perhaps, AWARE should have been more selective of its membership.  The question

Column: 441

of who should be given the right to vote has deep philosophical implications that would be applicable not only to AWARE, but philosophical implications for Singapore as well.


     Of the few protagonists involved in the saga, I would like to mention the role of the press in reporting this spat. One self-evident condition of a free press in a democracy is the need to be responsible, impartial and to present the facts as neutrally and objectively to the readers as possible. One wonders whether the press can be truly called upon to discharge that duty when some of its own members feel rather passionately about the issues in the public domain. The recent saga surrounding AWARE is but one example. I will quote one email that I received from one Ms Cheryl Ng. I must add that I do not know Ms Ng and I have not verified the substance of her email. However, I would say that I would not be surprised if it were true and would be very concerned if it is. Her email reads:

 

     "I'm also surprised and deeply troubled that the reporting in the Straits Times has not been honest in presenting the full picture to the public, especially concerned parents following the AWARE saga. There was a concerted effort by both the press and TV coverage not to mention the significant presence of the homosexual community. If I had not been there, I would never have known the truth.

 

     (a) In fact, I witnessed the main reporter responsible for blowing up the whole AWARE story ... hobnobbing with the homosexual fraternity at the EGM.


     (b) Some members of the press and TV were candidly jubilant as they celebrated the passing of the 'no confidence' vote by punching their fists in the air and hugging the 'old guard' they were standing with.


     (c) In the sweep of fervent support, the constitutional amendments were also made to allow men and foreign women full voting rights

Column: 442

(in a local women's association that makes the CEDAW report on the state of women in Singapore). In the perspective that such an amendment was thrown out in the previous AGM, the motives may be called into question. The press made no mention of this important development.

    

     I question the cover-up in the press.  In review of newspaper coverage of AWARE developments, I'm also beginning to think that press focus on the sensitive issues of religious involvement was but a calculated red herring thrown out to manipulate public sentiments.

    

      Sir, I am pleading for the authorities to look into this matter as I am becoming increasingly alarmed that minority groups with a political agenda may not have just reached its grasp into a vulnerable women's group, and through it attempt to distort our children's views on sexuality, but have actually infiltrated the press to block out news and prevent the public from accessing the truth. I actually feel frightened that the press in Singapore can attempt to shape my views as it wishes by misinformation or partial information."


     The accusations brought up by Ms Ng have once again raised the question of whether there should be an unregulated press. In reporting the matter, the editors and journalists could have looked at the issue as one of the conservative groups in our society taking on the liberals rather than be quick to frame this in the context of the Christian Right against the homosexuals and the lesbians. True, many of the ladies came from the same church.  However, the same may be said of any group who comes from any organisation.  But that alone does not mean that they represent the organisation.  I do wonder if the press would have been so quick on the take if it were women from another faith who took up the cause instead. It is unfortunate that by framing this episode as one that carries a religious undertone, the whole debate deeply polarised our society very quickly.

    

Column: 443

      Apart from the press, the Ministry of Education in the early days of the AWARE leadership struggle had maintained consistently that they did not look into this matter as no complaint was made by any parent.  Not surprisingly, what followed was a deluge of complaints from parents which then prompted an investigation by the Ministry.  The outcome was an implicit acceptance of the serious nature of the allegations against the CSE programmes run by AWARE.  I am grateful to note the Ministry has now tightened the procedures on the appointment of course providers in the area of sexuality education.

    

     The AWARE saga is as much about the kind of values we want to promote in our society as it is about leadership struggle. To build a socially cohesive society, all interest groups must recognise and accept the fundamental building blocks of our society that have come to represent our values on families and relationships. Our values change, if at all, by evolution than by revolution. Aggressive proselytisation by fringe groups, whether carried out by insidious means or otherwise, will only invite a backlash from mainstream society. This is not how our society should be run. Social cohesion requires the active participation of all. In this particular episode, one wonders if the Ministry of Education had taken a more proactive stand in the first place by being more vigilant, the leadership struggle and the ensuing polarisation of our community would not have taken place in the manner that it did. The question that some have asked is whether a formal complaint must be made from someone before the Ministry will act on a matter which it has heard about and which comes under its purview. Displaying annoyance at being dragged into the sorry saga does not help with the confidence recovery process in the aftermath.

    

Column: 444

     Sir, we have done extremely well as a country over the years, and I can say with great confidence that we will continue to do well in the years to come.  The President’s speech for the new session of Parliament has done much to reinforce that confidence.  The question is not whether we will do well, but how much better we will do. I strongly believe that if we are able to pull together and collectively work at overcoming the challenges that lie before us, there will always be a clear blue sky with a rainbow spanning over it for Singapore.

     The Minister of State for Defence (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, we meet at a historic moment. President Nathan laid out the challenges facing Singapore. A grave moment, a very grave moment, he cautioned.  Economically, Singapore has never witnessed a near collapse of world trade, travel and finance of this magnitude.  In Singapore’s short history, we have been confronted with all kinds of crisis but this one is perhaps the largest.  Prime Minister Lee warned at the May Day Rally speech that there is no V-shaped recovery this year for Singapore.  But, Sir, this crisis, however grave, however daunting, will pass.  The recovery may take a long time, or it may be next year, or the year after. The recovery may be a big U, or a huge W.  But in time, this crisis will be another case study in another MBA programme.  The question for us is not when or if this crisis will pass, but how it will pass. Will the recovery consume us, divide us and cut into our social foundations, or will it invigorate us and make us stronger, wiser and more united?  The world will move on  with or without Singapore.  We have to find our own way out of this quagmire.

 

Column: 445

     For too long, Sir, we have been told that solutions to economic and social problems lie with the private sector, not with the Government.  Bureaucracy became a dirty word in the west.  Felix Rohatyn, the distinguished banker who helped saved New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s and who later served as US ambassador to France in the 1990s said, "Americans by and large look at the government as the enemy."  They do not trust governments and have no faith in the bureaucracy.

 

     But, Sir, no sooner had the  financial tsunami struck, that the same people who put down bureaucracy began to clamour for more government assistance.  Even unthinkable concepts like nationalising  banks became a reality. These are unusual circumstances and old rules do not apply, they say.  Of course, they do.  When the US was faced with a crisis last year, Americans turned up in unprecedented numbers and gave President Obama and the Democrats an endorsement which left no one in doubt what Americans wanted in a time of crisis – they wanted a strong government.  The Democrats today control both ends of  Pennsylvania Avenue.  They control the House of Representatives, the Senate and the White House.  So what happened to checks and balances, laid out by the founding fathers of America?  Well, that can wait until the crisis is over.  The gravest moment in American history since the Depression demands unusual solutions.  Americans wanted strong leadership. America is a huge country – we call an economic aircraft carrier.  Singapore, by comparison, perhaps is a missile gun boat – fast, small, lethal but nonetheless quite small.  We need stronger leadership.


      When a nation is confronted with a defining moment like this one, we need to go back to basics and look to solutions to form a strong government, even as we are talking in this House about evolving

Column: 446

the political system and moving the political furniture.

 

     More than 2,500 years ago, Confucius saw a simple answer to a complex problem of governance and government. Confucius lived from 551 BC to 479 BC.  It was a period in China known as the 春秋时代 (Chun Qiu Shi Dai ) – a period of chaos, of anarchy, towards the end of the Zhou dynasty.  Confucius witnessed at close hand, poverty and hunger, war and corruption and harsh rule by power elites. Warring states were fighting each other for dominance.  It was during this period that he understood what people needed most. When asked by one of his students, 子贡 (Zi Gong), what were the ingredients that would make a nation strong so that the people could be happy and contented, Confucius replied him in three phrases and eight words : 足食, 足兵, 民 信之矣 (zu shi, zu bing, min xin zhi yi).     

 

     Let me explain.  He said 足食 (zu shi ), ie, the government must first provide the people with food.  In our modern context, this means the government must create an environment to create jobs for the people so that they will not starve.  With food, they can be happy and contented.  Second, Confucius said 足兵 (zu bing ) – you need a credible military deterrence to protect your people and the assets they have created, otherwise all will be lost. And, finally, he said 民 信之矣 (min xin zhi yi) – you need to trust and work with a good government.  You must have faith in this system in order to achieve social harmony and cohesion.


     When this disciple, 子贡 (Zi Gong), one of the cleverer ones, asked Confucius if he had to choose two of the three, what would Confucius give up?  Confucius paused for a moment and said, given no choice, he would let defence go.  The country would have to risk being attacked and people would have to live in fear and insecurity.  The nation and the people would be miserable.  Here, Confucius was often misunderstood to have relegated

Column: 447

defence to a lower priority. In fact, on the contrary, as I will explain later, Confucius thought defence was very, very important.

 

     But not satisfied, this discipline, 子贡 ( Zi Gong), asked Confucius again, what if he had to choose one of the remaining two?  Confucius replied without hesitation this time, and said, "Let the food go."

 

 

The disciple was flummoxed. He understood that without defence, their lives were imperilled, but without food they would face immediate death.

 

     Death, Confucius said, was not frightening because all mortals eventually die. What  was more frightening than death was the chaos and anarchy that came if a good government failed because people do not have faith in it.  He said in these few words, 去食，自古皆有死, 民无信不立 (qu shi, zi gu jie you si, min wu xin bu li ).  If the people have no faith in a good government, the  country would be finished, the country would suffer chaos, shame, humiliation, poverty and indignity.

 

     In answering the last question, Confucius made it clear that if a country was in chaos, anarchy and at war with each other, what was there to defend?  Defend against the enemy would be meaningless because you are fighting among yourselves. 
 

     The failure of a good government brings serious consequences to the people, not just during theChun Qiu Shi Dai, but throughout history.  The Chinese have a saying and they have gone through a long history, a few thousand years, they had through ups and downs, they had this saying,国富民强 (gou fu min qiang).  If you want to have pride and dignity, you want to have your voices heard in this Parliament, outside Parliament, the media or overseas, the country must be rich and

Column: 448

strong.  If the country is poor, the people will be weak and their voice will be meaningless.


     Last week, I read that a Hollywood actor made an intemperate remark about sending for a mail order bride from the Philippines on a late night TV show.  It was meant to be a joke, but you will agree it was a rather sick joke.  Sadly, the host joined in and said, "When you send for a mail order bride, please send me one too."   The Philippines government was indignant.  The Philippines community demanded an apology.  Indeed, such a racist and very insensitive remark should never have been articulated by the host and this famous Hollywood actor.  A Philippines senator complained that time and time again, people humiliate Filipinos by referring them as mail order brides and each time the government must protest and not let the matter rest.  So strong words indeed.  But words alone are not enough.

   

      Why do the rest of the world keep repeating these derogatory remarks, as suggested by the senator? There are many reasons.  Writing in the Sunday Times, our expatriate journalist in the Ex-Pat Files, Jervina Lao, lamented that the Philippines is "a country where hardly anything works without having to grease palms, where unemployment is high, where kidnapping is a cottage industry and where the economy depends on the government sending out its people to other countries as entertainers, maids and seamen, among other things."  Philippines is a thriving democracy.  It has a good government, but it has a weak government. 

 

     Young Singaporeans today speak with a confident voice.  Anybody can speak loudly.  But will you be heard?  When I was an overseas undergraduate in the early 1970s, Singapore was poor and weak.  My friends and I spoke often overseas.  I am not the quiet type, but we

Column: 449

were rarely heard.  In those days, Singapore was a nameless country.

 

     Many Australians called the Asians, Chinese in particular, "Ching Chong Chinamen".  Luckily, my name was not Ching or Chong, or not even a Wong, as I will explain later.  I protested.  I said, "I am not from China."  But they did not care.  They asked me, "Where is Singapore? A province in China?  Which city?"  Have you heard this derogatory remark like "Two Wongs  (wrongs) do not make a White (right)"?  If you are Mr Wong, you are in trouble.  And then when you pick up a number and say, "This is the Wong (wrong) number", or you are "Mr Wong (wrong)".  These are very racist jokes that we hear everyday. 

 

     I went on a scholarship given by the Australian Government to the Singapore Government.  For that, my friends and I are very grateful.  My stay in Australia gave me many good memories of the beautiful country and its mostly kind people.  But I came back convinced that if Singapore was poor, you and I had no dignity.  You do not count.  I do not count.  I was convinced that we needed a strong and good Government.  A good Government is necessary but not sufficient.  The Government must also be strong. And this good Government must bond with the people, and the people must have faith in this system, in this Government.

 

     Today, nobody will look down on Singaporeans because Singapore is strong and rich, and we have very credible defence force.  We have plenty of food.  We have satisfied all three requirements laid down by Confucius.

 

     But what can derail us?  What can bring us disaster?  This economic crisis cannot set us back permanently.  It is a passing thunderstorm.  But if we fall prey to religious and racial bigotry, then it will be a growing cancer in our society that will never go away.  Many of us see an increasing number of   Singaporeans

Column: 450

identifying themselves with their tribes, race and religion.  That, in itself, is nothing wrong but it must be seen and place in the right perspective and operated in the right environment.  But I see small groups becoming self-righteous and becoming intolerant of diversity.

  

     This intolerance may be our downfall.  Singapore is a multi-racial and multi-religious secular country which has succeeded not because you and I are perhaps more clever than our neighbours or more hardworking.  We have succeeded because of our system – it is a system that makes us strong and makes us rich.  Our system of tolerance, meritocracy, embrace of diversity and inclusiveness is very important.  Most countries with this combustible mix of  population and diversity of religions fail, and fail miserably.  One example is Sri Lanka.  For now, we are successful.  But we are still a young country. Far from improving that we are successful.  Far from improving that our success in peaceful co-existence can withstand the test of time.

 

     I remember the old Yugoslavia under the strong government of President Tito.  Yugoslavia was not a utopia.  It had many faults.  But it was a relatively peaceful country with reasonably good economic fundamentals.  Yugoslavia was the kind of  a role model for the Third World.  Yugoslavia showed the world how different people from different tribes, religions and ethnicity can live happily together.  But we know what happened today. Yugoslavia is past tense.  It is history.  It is kaput.  But it also destroyed the people, and it destroyed their happiness.


     Singapore is a city state much smaller than many global cities.  The global cities that have succeeded are those that are most progressive and dynamic.  They embrace diversity and tolerance in huge doses.  Two such cities come to my mind

Column: 451

immediately – New York City and London.  In London, where I used to live, nobody needs to feel like he or she is an alien or a weirdo.  There is a sanctuary for everybody. There is space for everybody to wander, explore, speak and differ.  This is the kind of tolerant and diverse society that we should aim to be.

   

     While we focus our energies on solving this economic crisis, Sir, we should never lose sight of the longer term challenge of building a tolerant, diverse and inclusive social infrastructure where everybody has a private space within the bigger common space and, most of all, we must have faith in the good Government, a strong Government.
