advantaged residents out on excursions.  At every outing, we invite volunteers to help out.  And at every outing, I see how bonds are built at all levels of society – volunteers from different walks of life, young and old, rich and poor, corporate partners and social workers.  I hope the Singapore Cares programme, to be implemented by MCYS, will build more of such bonds across the country.

 

     In these difficult times, Singapore also needs more help from those who can afford to give more. VWOs will have more work on their plate, and they will have to find innovative ways to raise funds.  When they do, I hope Singaporeans respond warmly.  If we take a long-term view, what is needed is to encourage younger Singaporeans to contribute as well, because if the young get hooked on giving, it will become second nature to them in time.  So it does not matter if their donations start small.  Every little bit counts, and the bits should grow bigger over the years.  For its part, MCYS has said that Family Service Centres (FSCs) will receive more resources to improve their service delivery.  I hope I can get an answer from the Ministry on how it will distribute these resources – based on need or equally across-the-board – and what sort of resources these are.  During the Budget debate, I had asked about the additional $15 million to be given to Government-funded VWOs and what the money would be used for.  I did not get a reply then.  I hope MCYS can give an update on this VWO contingency fund – how much has been disbursed, to whom and for what purpose?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the stormy weather from this financial crisis calls for volunteerism in Singapore to grow stronger.  The crisis also calls for help in the form of shelter by the Government.  The effects of the recession are starting to trickle down to all sections of society.  Last month, I was at Serangoon Junior College, and during a question-and-answer

Column: 453

session with the students, one of them asked me if I could do something about the economic crisis before I finish my term in Parliament because, and I quote, "We are all having a hard time".  I promised him I would do what I could.  While I still have not found the solution to the recession, I thought the most important thing I could do is to remind this House that the shelter we build must have place for every Singaporean.  The Government has come up with a broad-based package to mitigate the downturn.  And there has been some positive feedback.  But we must always be mindful of those who are more at risk of falling behind, namely, older workers and the differently-abled.

 

     We know it is more difficult for older workers to find employment.  The Government and the labour movement have consistently cajoled employers to hire older workers, even as we consistently hear anecdotes by older workers who have been passed over for a job.  Re-employment legislation is in the works, but in the meantime, the recession could cost many workers in their 50s their jobs.  I would like to make two suggestions which build on current schemes and initiatives.

 

     First, can the Government enhance the Jobs Credit Scheme for older workers by giving employers more credit for each worker above the age of 50 in their payroll?  This will incentivise the employers to give due consideration to hire and retain older workers.  The need for incentive when it comes to employment of older workers is a reality in Singapore.  For some years now, the Government has lowered the cost of employing older workers by reducing the CPF contribution rate for employers.  Re-employment legislation will also work on the norm that older workers can expect a smaller pay packet after the age of 62.  Since Jobs Credit already acts as an incentive for companies to retain

Column: 454

Singaporean workers, can we tweak it so that we do not end up with an unduly high number of older workers bearing the brunt of the recession?  After all, the Prime Minister announced on May Day a new scheme for fresh graduates to get internships, attachments and jobs – which is excellent.  More can also be done for older workers.

 

     Second, I would like to suggest that Singapore's Workforce Development Agency adapt a previous idea by NTUC, which not too long ago suggested that companies make public the age profile of their workforce.  WDA should do the same for all its SPUR programmes.  Given how important training and skills upgrading is currently and will continue to be, and the amount of money being spent on these efforts, greater transparency in this area can only be good and welcomed by the public.  It would also give the reassurance that re-skilling is not only for those in their 30s and 40s.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, we need to pull together with our older workers during these times.  We also need to pull together with fellow citizens with disabilities.  Every person can contribute to Singapore, and as our Paralympians showed last year, their contributions can be truly invaluable. Singapore must be as much a home for them as it is for able-bodied citizens.  So, I am very encouraged that the Ministerial Committee on Ageing has reaffirmed that all HDB housing estates will be barrier-free by 2011 and that a $60 million programme to do the same for pedestrian walkways, access to MRT stations, taxi and bus shelters and public roads will be completed by next year.  This goes hand-in-hand with the Ministry of Transport's move to improve accessibility and inclusiveness of the transport system.  It is important that these resources are spent well, and not wasted on the wrong implementation of barrier-free access.  We were told that HDB is working closely with the Town

Column: 455

Councils   

 

 

for the Barrier-Free Accessibility Programme.  The Town Councils are acting as the managing agent, presumably as they would have a much better feel of the ground and the solutions best suited for their residents.  But if a barrier-free environment is truly a priority of the Ministry of National Development (MND), I would like to see greater involvement by the Ministry, if only to ensure that an area of priority for the nation is implemented correctly.  It takes more than just ramps and lifts; seamless access is the only way Singapore can be transformed physically into a home for everyone.  I would like to see this attitude permeate at all levels of society.  

 

     One way to ensure this becomes a reality is for MND to audit the Town Councils to see if they are carrying out the national mandate to be inclusive.  If I may draw a parallel, the Ministry of Education (MOE) recently stepped in to tighten control and accountability in the engagement of external agencies for sex education, even though it had previously given autonomy to schools.  Likewise, I would like to see MND raise the level of accountability of Town Councils.

 

     I remember the President's Address in 2005 said that how Singapore treats and takes care of people with disabilities reflects the kind of society we want to be.  This must continue to hold true.  As we strive to get through this recession, we should remember that greater mobility for all will help us to pull together even better.  I would also like to seek reassurance from MOE, which did not mention special needs students in its addendum last week, that their future remains a priority for the Government.

 

     The final group that I would like to mention is the underprivileged and, especially during these times, those at the margins.  I am heartened that the Ministry

Column: 456

of Community Development, Youth and Sports (MCYS) will exercise more flexibility for this group.  I hope to hear more about what is being done. I am also heartened by MOE's announcement about the $68 million leg-up in Edusave and school-based financial assistance schemes.  I encourage the Government to continue to facilitate opportunities, for example, exchange and immersion programmes for the less privileged.  I would like to see these students continue to be given all the support they need whenever they chase their passions and pursue excellence. 

 

     I also hope we do not shy away from helping adult Singaporeans in need.  While there will always be a very small group of people who will have a crutch mentality, for example, by returning time and again to the Meet-the-People Sessions, I hope this does not adversely impact those who need a simple helping hand when globalisation knocks them off kilter, as would be the case in the current recession.  After all, since the Government has decided to go with the ebb and flow of globalisation, it must know that some people can get caught when the tides change suddenly.  Do we not throw them a lifeline on account of the behaviour of a small group of others?  A recent survey by the Institute of Policy Studies showed that Singaporeans are self-reliant for the most part and are eager to remain so.  But if we do not pull to safety those truly in need, then we are pulling ourselves apart.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I have touched on the people we must keep together by our side.  Now I would like to touch on the principles that we must hold on to closely as a nation, especially since Singapore is becoming more diverse, as a Straits Times commentary recently pointed out in the wake of recent events at AWARE.  Yes, we are becoming a more complex society, one with more voices being heard.  But we are no United States, with its 300 million population spread across a huge landmass 

Column: 457

– a country which can drive forward regardless of the kind of interaction among the different groups in society. 

 

     Singapore can be more diverse, more complex and have more voices, but we need to reach out to each other and not work against each other when we disagree.  We need to pull together, not pull apart when we want to move a debate forward in our small country.  And we need to remember some of the fundamentals that have brought Singapore success.  In particular, one of the cornerstones of our social cohesion has been meritocracy, which means that we advance based on merit and that Singaporeans are not denied opportunities because of certain attributes – race, language or religion as in the Singapore pledge, or essentially, who you are, where you come from, how much money you have or whether you are different.  We should pull together to strengthen meritocracy and, hence, social cohesion, not weaken it.  Otherwise, we are moving backward, not forward.

 

     Our progress is not just due solely to the efforts of Singaporeans and Singaporeans alone.  Foreign workers have worked together with us to build this country.  But lately, it almost seems as if the only way foreign workers can work with us is if they do not work here at all because otherwise, they are working against us by competing for jobs.  I sincerely hope that Singaporeans and foreign workers have not lost that ability to work together.  Even if we no longer occupy the social stratum of foreign workers – which is one of immigrants striving for a better future – we should not forget that is where our parents and grandparents' generation came from.


     Those are our roots and because those kind of roots were strong, we are where we are today.  On Monday, some hon. Members of this House asked for some jobs to be reserved for locals.  I believe in

Column: 458

putting Singaporeans first, but I do not think you need to do it by being protectionist.  Rather than "reserve" some jobs, employers could put Singaporeans first by only hiring a foreigner after they have proven that they could not find a local for the job.  This way, they are not artificially barred from hiring foreigners, even if no one here is suitable for the job.  I believe the hon. Member Dr Amy Khor suggested this a few years ago in this House, but the idea was rebuffed.  Perhaps it is time to look at it again?

 

     I believe it is also time that the Government carves out a space in our financial landscape for a micro-finance institution.  There is angst about foreign workers because many Singaporeans have no or very little alternative, but to compete with cheaper foreign workers for the same type of jobs.  But if we give them the opportunity to set up start-ups, we are expanding the available opportunities in Singapore.  These are not going to be the kind of SMEs that hope to become big brand names overseas, but small businesses that will provide a dignified and decent source of living.  Their beneficiaries are not likely to be your entrepreneurial university graduates, but Singaporeans who would not normally get credit approval with the usual banks even if they have a useful skill such as baking.  A micro-finance institution would certainly be useful.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, as we grapple with the recession and even after the economy recovers, we must, with every policy, consider how we are adding value to citizenship and by extension, strengthening national identity.  In that sense, I believe the decision to bid for the Youth Olympic Games (YOG) was a very good one, as such an event and others like it can help bring Singaporeans together.  I only wish that Singapore sports could be more inclusive of people with disabilities.  I did not see any mention by MCYS about developing sports for the disabled as part

Column: 459

of its plans and agenda in the years ahead.  It is great that a buzz is building for the YOG and the Asian Youth Games.  But what about the Special Olympics being held here next month, from 5th to 8th June?  There are about 700 athletes taking part in nine sports such as football, badminton and swimming.  They are the intellectually disabled, between the ages of eight and 40 or 50, and they come from Malaysia, Timor Leste, Indonesia, Myanmar, Brunei as well as Singapore.  But there hardly has been any public support for our team and the event.  We should be cheering them on.

 

     Singaporeans and the Government can strengthen national identity if we are able to better celebrate Singapore talent, such as the Singapore Women's Everest Team.  I am sure everyone is proud of them and cheers their achievement.  We should never underestimate the importance of such personal tales and triumphs because the more there are, the stronger the Singapore narrative grows.  One reason why we should always strive not to make policy too impersonal or rigid.  For example, I had previously asked in this House about the express stream entrance criteria for the School of the Arts.  I believe we will be able to nurture and celebrate a wider variety of artistic talent with a broader and more enlightened education policy.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, it is significant that we are celebrating 50 years of self-governance this year.  The tone of governance in Singapore has changed from one that insisted it was always right, to one that insists it will make the decisions, but after listening to the public who will then judge if those decisions were right.  Nobody can insist on always being right and hope others will come onboard and pull together as one.  This applies in all aspects of society.  Now that we have reached 50 years of self-

Column: 460

governance, perhaps eventually more decisions can be devolved from Government to a wider spectrum of society. 

 

     On Monday, the hon. Member Sam Tan lamented how Singaporeans may be too mollycoddled and reliant on the Government.  With due respect, perhaps Singaporeans would be less so if the political system were to be more devolved so that people are not just given a limited role to offer feedback, but instead be given a chance to actually exercise ownership and responsibility about their surroundings, their community and their country. 

 

     One good start, for example, is the work being done by Senior Minister of State Grace Fu in estate rejuvenation.  In the past, there tended to be a collective sentiment that the Government saw to everything, so the only thing left for Singaporeans to do was to complain.  That is why there have only been two cows in Singapore – and I apologise to Mr Speaker and the Members before saying this – "kau beh, kau bu".

 

     But in all seriousness, as the President said, our politics and our political system has to evolve.  With every passing year, we hear about the growing efforts needed to find fresh faces for political renewal.  I am sure many capable, passionate, young people would like to serve their country.  But if we are finding it so hard to find them, despite a more educated and diverse population, perhaps we need to allow for more diversity in Parliament and in our political system.  One of the biggest challenges for Singapore will be to nurture a new generation of leaders.  These future leaders have to ensure that an even more diverse Singapore will pull together, rather than pull apart, to ensure that no one is left behind and that all our talents are celebrated.  If it means the ruling party has to give up a little bit of control to find these leaders, then I say that Singapore's interests would be served well.

 

Column: 461

     Sir, with that, I support the motion.

 

 

     Mr Ang Mong Seng (Hong Kah) (In Mandarin):   [For vernacular speech, please refer to  Appendix A *.]  Mr Speaker, Sir, the 2008 global financial tsunami has dealt a heavy blow to Singaporeans.  Whether there will be a rebound in the economy, it is still not known.  Our immediate task is to help Singaporeans and businesses tide over this difficult period and survive, so that workers may keep their jobs.  Only then can we help them keep their rice bowls.  The problem that concerns us most is employment.


      According to MOM's statistics, in 2008, there were 16,880 workers who had lost their jobs, a figure which doubled from 2007.  The same statistics indicate that, of the 3,180 workers who lost their jobs in the third quarter, 70% of them had found new jobs at the end of last year.  This should be attributed to the coordination between MOM and NTUC as it continues to get workers to go for skills training and, hence, we are able to achieve good results even during this difficult period. 

 

     Minister Lim Swee Say mentioned that the non-unionised companies’ order books for the second quarter are better than those of the first quarter and the number of workers retrenched would be substantially less. But, because of low margins, companies’ profits would be reduced. While the second quarter’s economic performance has been better, the worst is not over yet. Many companies are still cautious on hiring workers. 

 

     MOM announced a piece of good news – the two IRs will start hiring 45,000 workers for the next two years.  The public service will also create 18,000 jobs. 

 

     Figures from the Community Development Councils (CDCs) also indicate that

Column: 462

up to now, there are about 20,000 vacancies of different grades at various sectors waiting to be filled.  This is good news to those who are looking for jobs. 

 

     However, at my Meet-the-People session, I still see many people who complain of not having a job.  They have been jobless for some time.  When CDC holds job fairs, thousands of people flock to these fairs to look for suitable jobs.  Most of them are middle-aged and old people.  Thus, the unemployment situation is still grave. To further understand certain situations, we need to carry out an in-depth study of the problems and find suitable solutions. 

 

     The radio station 958 interviewed some bosses who employed local workers.  They said that some worked for two days and left.  But some of the jobless complained that bosses like to employ only foreign workers.  After the interview, the employer asked them to wait for the phone call from the company; however, they waited at home but did not receive any phone call.  So who is right then?  The boss or the worker? 

 

     I would  like to ask the Minister whether his Ministry has any comprehensive data on the jobless for all the constituencies, including their work experience and background. If no, I suggest that the MOM carry out such a survey.  With this data, we will be able to know the exact number of jobless so that we can better find jobs for them. And this data will also come in handy when MPs and grassroots leaders visit the constituencies to familiarise themselves with the residents' problem and, perhaps, help them find jobs. I believe this will be a thorough way to solve the unemployment problem. 

 

     Now, let me talk about the challenges brought about by the ageing population

Column: 463

and the strategy that we would need to take to deal with them. 

 

     Right now, out of 12 Singaporeans, one is 65 years old and above.  By 2030, the ratio will be one to five, ie, 20% of the population.  If, by then, our population is five million, there will be one million who will be 65 years and above. Sir, it is imperative for us to make preparations for such eventuality. Minister Lim Boon Heng, who is in charge of policies on ageing population, has stressed that the Government has launched a number of measures.  For example, HDB has installed lifts at every level of HDB flats and lift upgrading programmes will be completed by 2014.  The Ministry of National Development has carried out work on barrier-free walkways for the disabled and elderly island-wide. 

 

     With regard to taking care of the physical needs of the senior citizens, we must pay attention to their mental health. To foster good mental health among elderly, we must ensure that active senior citizens have adequate space to engage in activities during the day.  I have proposed in the House that to achieve optimum results, Residents' Committee (RC) should take charge of all activities for senior citizens in the precinct.  The current centres for activities are not fully utilised and managed properly. Every care centre should be located near RC offices and managed by them. This is because every RC has a branch in the community to render help to the residents; it will be convenient for the residents and senior citizens to make use of such facilities. 

 

     RC is a non-profit making body without any sources of income.  They are about 554 RCs currently. They can better provide services for the senior citizens.  I hope that MCYS would accept the above suggestions. 

 

Column: 464

     As the RC is a non-profit making body without any sources of income, if they are to have more spaces for activities, they will have to pay the increased rental to HDB.  The current rental of $1.30 psf, though not expensive, is a big burden to a body without any income.  I, therefore, suggest that HDB charge a nominal rent only. 

 

     To encourage the elderly to carry out healthy lifestyle activities, we should encourage them to go outdoors, or visit the various places of interests. Currently, the admission charges for places of interest are too expensive for senior citizens. To encourage more senior citizens to visit such places, I suggest concessionary rates be given to senior citizens who are 60 and above, and they should be given half price. Those who are 70 years and above should enjoy free admission. This is in appreciation of the contributions that they have put in for the country. Many countries have done so and we should do the same. 

 

     Lastly, I would like to talk about our public service culture.  I agree with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, Mr Teo Chee Hean, who is also Minister in-charge of the Civil Service.  Mr Teo said that it is important for the civil servants to keep in close touch with ground concerns.  In the Addendum to the President's Address, he mentioned that the focus of the public service is to keep in close touch with ground concerns, in order to formulate policies that are relevant to the needs of all Singaporeans. This will ensure that the immediate measures needed to mitigate the effects of the downturn on Singapore and Singaporeans are carried out effectively and with empathy.  He stressed that public service leaders must serve the people of Singapore with integrity and empathy.  In this regard, I would like to share with Members three examples.  If civil servants serve with the right attitude, it will enable them to effectively manage the needs and

Column: 465

problems of the people and improve their service delivery to the public. 

 

     The first example is regarding multi-storey carparks.  The residents of Hillview Avenue had moved to Bukit Batok West Avenue 5 because their flats were under construction.  Residents parked their vehicles at the open carparks or multi-storey carparks.  These residents did not face any problems parking their cars in the open carparks.  However, the multi-storey carparks did not have bumper curbs or parking lot curbs.  So, when they reversed their car too much, the bumper would knock onto the wall, crashing the rear lights of the vehicle.  If they were not careful, and if they reversed too much, the car would hit the wall.  It would cost them a few hundred dollars to repair the bumper and rear lights. In this regard, I had given feedback to the HDB engineer but the response given was that these multi-storey carparks were built according to the standards and specifications by the Land Transport Authority.  They suggested that drivers should go head in when they park their cars and not reverse in. In this way, they will not knock onto the wall.  They said it would be difficult to implement this suggestion.  And so I invited them to come down for an on-site visit so that they could have a close look at the problem.  Eventually, he accepted my suggestion and they installed a few parking lot curbs. It has been three years since we implemented the pilot project, and we received very good response from the residents. Here, I would like to thank the engineers of HDB because they have installed bumper curbs and parking lot curbs for all the carpark lots in the multi-storey carpark and the residents are very pleased about it. 

 

     Second example. From Bukit Batok MRT station to the housing estate, the walking distance is about 200 metres.  I noticed that many residents like to walk on the grass patch near the MRT track.  But on rainy days, the muddy ground can be very slippery.  Therefore, I propose to

Column: 466

LTA to build a concrete pedestrian pavement near the MRT track. Similarly, it was rejected by LTA.  The reason given was that under the current provisions, they do not allow construction structure of any kind near MRT tracks. Fortunately, LTA sent an officer down for an on-site visit and they also spoke to some residents to get their response.  So when the HDB officer returned to his office, he put up a proposal for the building of a concrete pedestrian pavement, for the benefit of those hundreds and thousands of residents using the pavement every day.  Today, residents no longer have to worry about the slippery pavement or the hot sun anymore.  Mayor Amy Khor goes for jogging every morning along the pavement and she complimented that this pavement serves the residents very well and she told me, "Excellent, very good!"  Thank you, Mayor. 

 

     Third example.  HDB has been looking for cost-effective lifts for installation at all HDB flats so that we can serve the residents better.  I happened to know that other countries have already implemented such "lift without machine room" and it helped to save 20% of the construction costs.  However, when I first suggested this idea to Minister Mah Bow Tan, Minister Mah informed the HDB engineers about the idea.  It was rejected.  The reason was that the system is noisy and it is not suitable for Singapore.  So, I invited the HDB engineers for a study visit to Shanghai so that they can understand the system better.  In the end, we all realised the installation is much cheaper and faster; also, the noise is minimal.  Upon returning to Singapore, they proposed to Minister Mah Bow Tan to allow the installation of "lift without machine room" for our HDB estates.  This has resulted in a 20% cost-savings for us. 

 

     As you can see, the above examples showed that if the public service officers can be there on the ground to understand more about the issue; if they are creative,

Column: 467

if they are bold, they will be able to formulate policies that are relevant to the needs of the people and better serve the people. 

 

     Generally, civil servants will not change the policies once they are passed. I can understand this. However, we must also move with the times. Civil servants, therefore, must learn from the athletes, adopt the mentality of an athlete, ie, to constantly improve one's skills.  Because once an athlete breaks the world record, he or she will look into other ways of improving his or her skills, in order to break another record. 

 

     Since Singapore gains its independence, we do not have any natural resources. In such a short period of 40 years, we have moved on from a Third World country to a modern and developed country today. Clearly, this is because we have capable leaders.  Our leaders possess great foresight.  They review and refine policies. We progress and we move on with the times.  And that is why we managed to achieve the success we have today.  Civil servants have put in a lot of hard work and contributed to our success today.  So, let us work together. I believe we can continue to work with all Singaporeans to buildour nation's future.

    

     I support the motion.

     Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, pundits are talking about the possibility of a lost decade that is a result of a long drawn-out financial crisis, out of which a "Grave New World" could emerge.  Today, the collective sense is that we are only at the beginning of a long road we all need to undertake as a nation.

 

Column:468

     The President's key message is this is not a time to panic or resort to short-term protectionist measures, but rather to focus our energies on what has allowed Singapore to succeed globally, and let us better our competitive advantages.

 

     I could not agree more.  During the Budget debate earlier this year, I had said that we should use this financial crisis as an opportunity to review and re-look at the way we do things.  After the excesses of the global financial industry over the past 10 years – that feeling of invincibility that proved fatal – let us re-focus on the basics and strengthen our fundamentals.
 

     The crux of our strong foundation as a nation has always been, and will always be, the strength of our people – the strength of their skills – their mentality, and their will to combat challenges.  On top of that we are fortunate to have strong leadership and institutions like NTUC and the CDC at the forefront in helping our workers to re-skill and upgrade them to ensure continued employability, and put retrenched workers back into employment.

 

     Since the beginning of this year, at the CDC, we have seen the number of people seeking jobs doubled compared to last year: from an average of 400 per month last year to about 800 per month this year. The good news is that despite the downturn, there are jobs.  But we are all overly challenged and have to be more prepared to work harder, because for every 50 jobs available, there are some 100 job seekers.

 

     Ironically, the only way to combat the "Grave New World" situation is to be even more optimistic and positive.  Mindset will determine whether one lands that job or not.  Stay positive.  Be willing to take work beyond your scope and be proactive in the search.

 

     Allow me, Sir, to share real-life example:  Mr Sng Kok Tong, 40 years old, 

Column: 469

had worked as a futures trader for 16 years and was previously earning more than $5,000.  He even brushed shoulders with famed rogue trader, Nick Leeson, who brought down the Barings Bank.  Recently, at a job fair held by the CDC in March for precision and transport engineering, Mr Sng was looking for a job as a welder and a crane-driver.  The father of two said: "I started from zero. There is nothing wrong with starting from zero again. I'm prepared to retrain and work shifts and weekends for my family."

 

     Sir, I hope more will learn from his admirable example.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, while workers must continue upgrading and re-skilling, companies must improve productivity by investing in capital and technology to leverage on the higher skills of our workers.  In the last decade or so, we have seen the outsourcing practice becoming a common mode of operation for companies. Most gave cutting costs as their reason, others claimed those activities are not their core business.  Whatever it may be, as a result, many workers now end up working for contractors who are providing services that range from manufacturing, cleaning, landscaping, security, etc.  The number of contract and casual workers in Singapore has grown to more than 180,000 and it is still growing.  Unfortunately, Sir, all is not well for this group of workers.  On behalf of the contract and casual workers, I would like to call upon the service buyers to be more vigilant and involved when they outsource their contracts. 

 

     Recently, it was reported on 14th May that seven employers were charged for employment violations, which included unauthorised salary reductions, excessive working hours and failure to provide statutory employment benefits.  Besides these seven, another 17 were also charged for similar offences earlier and are

Column: 470

awaiting for court mentions.  Some of them will only pay up after multiple interventions by the authorities.  During our interactions with workers, we do come across bad practices of employers.  Often, the workers earn low wages and are lowly educated.  They do not know their rights and are afraid to come forward for fear of losing their jobs.  In this economic climate, contract workers are also hit.  We are aware that companies may not see the need to renew their contracts due to low business volume.  Companies are also impacted by the downturn and some have resorted to cheap sourcing as part of their cost-cutting measures. 

 

     There are many reasons why workers are short-changed.  Allow me to list some of these reasons for Members' benefit:

 

     Firstly, service providers could be in financial difficulties and may lack operating funds.  Some of them have too many contracts on hand and cannot deliver quality service.  They get penalised for poor performance regularly and are unable to pay up those liquidated damages.

 

     Secondly, contracts are awarded based on the cheapest quote, and the easiest to cut cost is, of course, salaries and benefits of workers or requesting workers to work excessive hours.

 

     Thirdly, many contract specifications do not include requirements such as requiring service providers to provide written employment contract to workers, stating working hours, salary and benefits besides the normal performance standards.  Workers also do not know their terms of employment.  We have seen workers' salaries remaining stagnant for many years.  This is exacerbated, Sir, by the complete lack of audit or assessment on the performance of the service providers once the contract is awarded, for example, check on whether there is a

Column: 471

written employment contract for their workers and their working hours.  Basic questions that could be asked by service buyers are: why is a particular worker working seven days per week without rest?  Or why workers are not given annual leave or sick leave?

 

     Fortunately, Sir, though these things are still happening, moving forward, we believe that all is not lost. There are ways that the situation can be improved.  All relevant parties that are involved in the outsourcing phenomena must play their part and not use legalistic position to excuse themselves of their responsibilities.  We feel that service buyers can help to put a stop and weed out the service providers and contractors who have been recalcitrant. Work with those with established track records because this is more sustainable and beneficial for the company in the long run.  Check their background thoroughly as some of them can set up a new company under a different name.  It is easy to register as a sole-proprietor and run a labour supplier business with low capital outlay.  We must support genuine companies who invest in improving their operations and productivity through mechanisation to raise the productivity of workers; train their workers to increase their efficiency and, most importantly, adhere to the employment legislation and treat the workers well.

 

     Sir, we have also engaged companies who are good employers and who have embraced and practised the Tripartite Advisory on Responsible Outsourcing.  We could tell that their workers are generally happier and they can see career progression with their employers.  The company is able to provide value-added services to their service providers who are willing to pay for good service.  Their relationship with the service buyer is

Column: 472

"win-win" and both can see long-term mutual benefits in their relationship.

 

     Though we know that such problems will continue to exist, as they say there will always be some rotten eggs, we do hope that the rest of us can do our part and be more involved when it comes to helping our fellow workers to earn a decent living for themselves and for their families.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, in the grave scenario of a lost decade, resources are tight and the social safety net will become ever more strained.  But more than ever, greater numbers of people will need help.  It will become tempting to walk down the path of a welfare state and I am telling you this is a true pressure.  Historically, key social welfare systems that defined welfare states were created in the aftermath of difficult times.  The British welfare state, embodied by the National Healthcare System (NHS) was created after World War II.  The US Social Security Act was part of Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal in response to the Great Depression.

 

     At the CDC, we have begun to see the signs of the needy seeking help increased by about 40%, from 800 on the average per month in 2008 to about 1,100 per month average in 2009.  Fortunately, help is available.  Last year alone, Central Singapore CDC spent more than $17.6 million through national and local schemes helping some 12,000 low-income households and this in partner with the VWOs and also the social services organisations on the ground.  But, Sir, continuing welfare cannot be the only answer. It is only a short-term solution. Again, we must re-visit the fundamentals:

 

     Firstly, education.  I applaud the move by Ministry of Education (MOE) to increase the amount of Edusave per child.  I believe that, given the tightest squeeze on national resources, spending on education remains sacrosanct.

 

Column: 473

     Secondly, we have to look at sustainability.  We have seen from other countries' examples that a cradle-to-grave welfare system, of which the state is the main provider, is unsustainable. But how do we have a balance, with the growing need for assistance to low-income families who are stuck in a poverty cycle?  Sir, in my view, community self-help must be the cornerstone of our framework of help for the community.  We could recall, back in colonial days, when there were none or minimal help from the Government, clans, associations and religious groups filled the gap for help. Today, I hope that privileged individuals, successful businesses and foundations continue to come forward to lend a helping hand.

 

     Thirdly, Sir, we need better coordination of deployment of resources.  There need to be a more concerted effort and we need to co-opt community self-help into the larger national network of social assistance.  The CDC's ComCare Local Networks (CLN) have been doing so since 2007.  Today, while there are "Many Helping Hands", we hope they come forward to be more coordinated in working with the CDC so that we minimise duplication and maximise use of our resources.

 

     Fourthly, Sir, I believe we need to promote more social innovation and entrepreneurship. Fuse commercial goals with social mission so that serving social needs becomes self-sustaining over the long run. The US is leading the way.  There are some social entrepreneurs here, but Singapore is still in a very fledgling phase.  More could be done to help social entrepreneurs fulfil their mission in Singapore.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, though I am elated by the recent announcement of more tertiary institutions for Singaporeans, I am hoping for more to be done in the pre-school sector.  The early childhood sector has

Column: 474

seen many new developments in the recent months.  These initiatives, introduced by MCYS and MOE, seek to raise the standards of the early childhood sector and enhance the accessibility and affordability of early childhood education in Singapore.

Column: 475

Childhood Diploma courses, the sector still sees higher attrition rate.

 

 

     Many cited low recognition and low pay being the main reason for leaving. In addition, existing teachers without the new minimum qualifications would drop out if bridging courses are not introduced quickly.  With 200 new centres targeted and estimated 2,000 job openings in childcare sector over the next five years, the sector can expect to see an acute shortage of qualified teachers in the short run.

Pre-school teachers are as important, if not more important in the preparatory stage of a formal education compared to primary school teachers.

This would complement the nation's effort in raising standards and help attract and retain entrants into the sector.

The workgroup's immediate priority is to raise the profile of the sector to encourage new entrants such as PMETs who were out-placed to enter the sector.

 

     We believe, Sir, that with better qualifications, the teachers' value adds to the sector and, in turn, parents do not feel

Column: 476

short-changed when centres raise fees to cover the increase in teachers' salaries in the future.

 

     I would like to call for greater support from the Government to raise the profile of the pre-school sector and for more recognition of the contribution of the pre-school teachers and that all stakeholders view and treasure them as Pre-school Professional.

 

     Competition amongst different interests for limited resources will be brought more starkly into relief during difficult times.  We must prevent stresses on our social fabric by appreciating one another more during these times.  We must learn to accept, even embrace, our differences – be they national, race, religious, or upbringing – as they make Singapore a unique multi-cultural society. By all means, hold on to our beliefs and our views, but respect the fact that not everyone or everybody will share them. We must learn to agree to disagree.

     We should also, Sir, smile more, be gracious, I think we are too serious sometimes. We could all use some uplifting during these difficult times.

 

     I know that some workers may have to experience temporary layoff, but we could always look at the positive angle, those mandatory unpaid leave or temporary layoff, could be a blessing in disguise to spend more time with your family and friends and reconnect.

 

     In conclusion, Sir, I would like to thank the President for his speech. He spoke about maintaining our economic competitiveness; strengthen social cohesion, focus on the importance of

Column: 477

education, amongst others.  It is now every Singaporean's duty – in your capacity as husbands and wives, fathers and mothers, workers and employers, leaders of organisations – to figure out exactly how we as individuals can help to build Singapore's future in an uncertain world, as that the next decade become not a lost one because Singapore, as a country, is always looking forward to work harder and to achieve even more in the next decade.

     Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I support the motion standing in the name of the Member for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, Mr Michael Palmer, to thank the President for his Address.

 

     In the first global "stress test" performed by Swiss business school, International Institute for Management Development (IMD), Singapore was ranked second, after Denmark, to be among the best prepared to withstand the economic stresses of a recession.  At second, out of 57 nations surveyed, we are deemed to be well-placed to weather the financial crisis and improve our competitiveness after we emerge from it.  However, the President's Address underscored the fact that the global

Column: 478

environment is capricious and that we can ill afford to be caught wrong footed to our economy's detriment.  I agree and wish to speak about four main points arising from the direction the President set in his Address.

 

     First, jobs.  The President stated, "We must keep up the effort to up-skill and re-skill our workers to become more employable and productive, in a changing economy" and that "NTUC is at the forefront of these efforts, working shoulder to shoulder with Government and employers."  It is against this backdrop that I wish to discuss the Skills Programme for Upgrading and Resilience (SPUR) programme, the 18,000 public sector jobs the Government will release into the labour market and the need to tweak and fine-tune the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) Scheme.  An article on 20th May 2009 in the Business Times reported that according to the latest Kelly Global Workforce Index, five out of six local professionals believe they could become irrelevant if their skills are not upgraded within the next five years.  Workers are more pressed than ever in the present age to keep upgrading their skills.  The Government's willingness to drive and sponsor this is the right move.

     Next, the 18,000 public sector jobs.  The Government announced in Budget

Column: 479

2009 that it would be making available 18,000 public sector jobs over the next two years.  How many of these 18,000 jobs have been taken up?  How many people have applied so far?  And how successful have the advertising campaigns been to generate a good response to these recruitment drives?  I ask these questions because I have met constituents in my constituency, Ulu Pandan, who have the requisite skills to serve well in Government jobs, but are still unaware of the Government's recruitment drives.

 

     Next, WIS.  Currently, if a worker's monthly income is less than $1,500 and he is above 35-years old, he will receive the WIS from the Government.  WIS was introduced to encourage an increased rate of employment and to signal to Singaporeans that the Government will, where employment policy is concerned, walk shoulder-to-shoulder with Singaporeans if they make the effort to work.  Therefore, we should reward those who work harder.  On this note, why not offer WIS to workers who have a basic salary of $1,500 or less, even if their over-time pay tilts their monthly pay cheque to beyond $1,500?  This way, to echo my fellow Member of Parliament, Mdm Halimah Yacob, we will not be discouraging the diligent workers from working hard.  The Government would have to pay WIS based on $1,500 and not on the accumulative figure of basic salary plus overtime pay.  Where is the harm in that?


     Next, I would like to discuss issues relating to national security.  The President had stated, "Mas Selamat's recapture is not the end of the terrorism threat."  And in a later part of the Address, the President stated, "Maintaining a safe and secure Singapore is a basic pre-condition for our people to pursue their dreams."
 
     With these two statements in mind, I would like to compliment the Home Team

Column: 480

and Internal Security Department (ISD), in particular, for playing an active role in the recapture of Mas Selamat.  It has been a trying and difficult year for ISD, but its resilience has paid off.  To me, ISD's perseverance in tracking down Mas Selamat displayed true tenacity.  They overcame adversity.  Indeed, MHA's own statement in the addendum to the President's Address sums up the ever changing parameters in the anti-terrorism business and I quote:

 

     "How we achieve safety and security will change over time as our operating realities and society change.  The operating environment today is complex and challenging."


     Therefore, the recapture of escaped terrorist leader, Mas Selamat, has set many minds at ease.  Nonetheless, the question on the top of many Singaporean minds is how he managed to cross our border with Malaysia?  Consequently, Singaporeans are concerned about the fact that he may have had sympathisers in Singapore who helped him travel to Malaysia.  It is encouraging that the security forces of regional countries, in particular ISD and the Malaysian Special Branch, continue to work closely together to combat the threat of terrorism.  In the case of Mas Selamat, the cooperation has borne fruit.  When the time is appropriate, I hope the Minister for Home Affairs will answer the questions on the minds of many Singaporeans, ie, how he escaped, whether there were JI sympathisers who helped him and, if so, how many?  Now that he has been recaptured, how should we deal with him, going forward?  What measures do we have in place to prevent a repeat of such an incident?

 

     The third point I would like to address is the issue of the prevalence of loanshark attacks in Singapore.  The President had stated in his speech: "Challenging times will put stresses on our society and our families, but we must manage these stresses and meet the challenges as one

Column: 481

people."  One stress line is the rising debt owed to loansharks.  On 22nd May 2009, the Straits Times reported:

 

     "Sales of CCTV cameras, alarms jump - More residents fear crime, loan sharks."

 

I quote from the article:

 

     "Police also received nearly 4,000 complaints of loanshark harassment ... in the first three months of this year, up from 2,066 complaints in the same period last year."


     I welcome the Home Affairs Minister's decision announced earlier this year to seriously consider making borrowing from illegal moneylenders a crime.  Let me explain why.

 

     In January last year, Senior Minister of State, Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee, informed that there were 10,221 reported cases of unlicensed moneylending in 2006.  That was a 19% increase over 2005 when there were 8,568 reported cases.  Similarly, the 2005 figure represented an increase of 47%, to be exact, over 2004, which had 5,809 reported cases.  Multiple initiatives were introduced by Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) to try to solve the problem.  These included:

 

     (a)  Enhancing the penalties under the Moneylenders Act; and

 

     (b)  The formation of the Anti-Unlicensed Moneylending (UML) Task Force to increase, among others, the number of ambush operations.

 

     However, the figures show that these measures have not deterred loansharks syndicates.  A look at the statistics for 2007 support this point.  In 2007, there were 277 arrests over the first three quarters, ie, from January to September, which were just 17 short of the total number of arrests for the whole of 2006. 

 

Column: 482

     Thus, in the light of the unattractive figures quoted above, MHA is correct to consider taking a different strategy in tackling the very real problem of unlicensed moneylending.  This involves simultaneously tackling the supply of and the demand for illegal loans.  Currently, the law, called the Moneylenders Act, curbs UML only by deterring the supply of illegal loans into the market.  It does nothing to penalise or deter the borrowing, ie, the demand side.  This is clear from sections 8(1)(b) and (c) of the Moneylenders Act.  The offences in these sections do not deter the demand for illegal loans.  Introducing a new section which makes it an offence if a person secures a loan for himself or on behalf of any other person from an unlicensed moneylender will help deter the demand.  The punitive measures which come along with the offence can be calculated based on the harm that the State deems such borrowing creates and based on the level that will best deter such activities.  Naturally, the Attorney-General will have the ultimate discretion whether to prosecute a borrower, and unique circumstances prompting a compassionate approach would likely merit non-prosecution.

 

     Examples of two prominent pieces of legislation which combat both the supply and demand elements of an offence are the Misuse of Drugs Act (MDA) and the Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA).  Sections 5 to 7 of the MDA penalise the trafficking, import and export and manufacture of controlled drugs, ie, the supply of them.  But, significantly, section 8 of the MDA also penalises the possession and consumption of controlled drugs, ie, the demand for them.  By penalising both the demand and supply, the drugs problem in Singapore has been contained.

 

     The second prominent piece of legislation is the Prevention of Corruption

Column: 483

Act (PCA).  Section 5(a) of the PCA penalises the supply of corruption, and in order to effectively deter acts of corruption in Singapore, section 5(b) of the PCA penalises the demand for corruption.  Thus, both the demand and supply of elements of corruption are tackled in tandem, resulting in Singapore's extremely low incidence of corruption.  We should quickly use the same strategy to combat the rapid growth of unlicensed moneylending in Singapore, given that:

 

     (a)  The anecdotal evidence that a significant number of those borrowing from loansharks are using the loan to pay off gambling debts;

 

     (b)  As a result, innocent residents have to bear the brunt of harassment if a false residential address is given;

 

     (c)  The whole corridor suffers the stigma of graffitied walls even if a false address is not given;

 

     (d)  The continuing Government philosophy that if we continue to work, we will be given an incentive, such as WIS, why not make borrowing from illegal moneylenders, which causes much harm to the neighbourliness of communities, an offence?

 

     The Attorney-General is always in a position to exercise his discretion whether or not to prosecute the borrower based on the unique mitigating factors, if any.  I urge MHA to quickly implement the policy which includes a shift away from supply-centric enforcement to one which also combats the demand.  This would be similar to the two-pronged enforcement action taken against drugs and corruption.  Would MHA therefore provide an update of when it will introduce provisions which make borrowing from loan sharks an offence?

 

Column: 484

     I move onto my fourth and last point - education and easing the load placed on teachers.  The President made clear: "Education is our best investment in Singapore's future. Our education system is designed to give each and every child the best opportunity to stretch his abilities."

     While I fully agree, I wish to add that to achieve this, we need to give teachers the space and time to teach.  During the Budget debate this year, MOE announced that it would make available close to 7,500 teaching positions and teaching support staff for our schools and tertiary institutions.  Given, the high expectations placed on our teachers, a topic I have talked about in this House several times, I would like to ask the Minister for Education how many teaching support staff has MOE recruited, what its target in terms of recruitment of teaching staff is for 2009 and how near is MOE to that target.

 

     In conclusion, Sir, our GDP is expected to decline by 6%-9% this year, with unemployment set to rise. We need to unite as a people to overcome the challenges ahead.  But we should not forget that we have in the meantime a nation to keep safe, children to teach and our social fabric to protect.  In supporting the motion, I trust the Government will consider the four points I raised in relation to Mas Selamat, reducing the incidence of loansharking, SPUR, WIS and the injection of 18,000 public sector jobs into the labour market and education.

 

 

     The Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Mr Heng Chee How): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you very much for allowing me to speak on this motion of thanks to the President.  I am very happy to see such a packed House today and I am sure that Members are eagerly awaiting what I have to say. 

 

     A reporter once asked an old communist revolutionary to describe the

Column: 485

merits of his system.  So the comrade said, "Our system is great because everyone has a job".  The reporter then asked, "Well, that is wonderful.  So how is your pay related to your work?"  And the comrade answered, straight forward, "They pretend to pay me, I pretend to work."

 

     Sir, this is, of course, a joke, but I think it does tell us something about how the design of political systems interplay with basic human motivations to produce outcomes for better or for worse.  Singapore has come a long way since our independence; economically, socially and politically.  Our strategic choices have mostly paid off and that is why we are in a better position today compared with most of the other small colonies that gained independence after the war.  We have to make new strategic choices in the face of fast-changing circumstances.  The Chinese saying "Bu jin ze tui", that is, "If we cannot advance, we will surely slide back" describes the difference between getting it right and getting it wrong.  For today, I will focus on three areas that, in my view, have the potential to disrupt our social fabric and undermine our economic strength.  These three areas are employment of older workers, treatment of lower wage contract workers and the treatment of foreign workers.

 

 

     First, I will speak on the employment and the re-employment of older workers.  There is now a new term in the United States and it is called, "Un-retirement".  This is a phenomenon where retired workers are forced by circumstances to return to the workforce to seek a living.  What happened, why do they have to do that?  These retirees have run out of savings, or lost their savings to stock market plunges.  They have also seen the value of their homes collapse.  "Un-retiring" is proving to be much more difficult than frustrating and sometime heart wrenching than retiring.  Just

Column: 486

because you are broke and need money, does not mean that you would be given priorities for your job and this is especially so when the economy in itself shedding drops in the face of a recession.  But then where does that leave the distraught? 

 

     And we look at the situation in Singapore.  We, in Singapore are also facing our most serious recession since the war.  Thankfully, we have avoided the worst outcomes in the labour market so far.  Although GDP fell from 7.8% in 2007 to 1.1% in 2008 and to an expected between -6% and -9% for this year, the rise in the quarterly unemployment rate, that is as of first quarter 2009, to 3.2% overall and 4.8% for the local workforce has not been as steep.  I firmly believe that this is partly because of the unemployment retarding effects of the Jobs Credit Scheme, the SPUR programme, the socially responsible company level cost cutting on the one hand, and the actual job searching, job retraining and placement efforts by entities such as the CDCs and NTUC, e2i on the other. 

 

     On the re-employment front, the number of unionised companies committed to re-employing older workers stands at 726 as at the end of April 2009.  And the total number of workers in unionised companies employed beyond age 62 has also gone up from around 4,600 at the end of last year to more than 5,000 by the end of first quarter 2009.  But does this mean that we need not worry about the prospects of the re-employment for older workers and does "un-retirement" hold any lessons for Singapore? 

 

     In my view, we should take very seriously the difficulties of workers attempting "un-retirement".  When we studied the write-ups, we see that many of these retirees say that they are stuck because they cannot convince employers of their employability.  And those who

Column: 487

have left work for a number of years are particularly out of touch skills-wise, and also through a lack of confidence.  Others are ruled out because of the healthcare cost that prospective employers do not want to shoulder and, yet, others rule themselves out because they continue to look for work in sectors and at terms that they were used to but which are no longer realistic. 

 

     Although these kinds of descriptions are coming out of the US, these descriptions are not unfamiliar to us.  If you try to remedy these problems and close the gaps quickly for large numbers in a moment of crisis, it would be a most difficult challenge for any country to tackle.  The key lesson is that we must do our best not to end up in that situation, as far as possible.  And that is by going upstream and helping as many of our workers stay employed and employable for as long as possible.  Hence, our efforts in the area of re-employing older workers must not slacken, even in the face of the downturn.

 

     To be realistic, we must expect that it would not be easy securing re-employment in the downturn and the numbers that I shared just now, they do not say they are easy, they just prove that the extra effort that I have to go into in entrenching the practice of re-employment in companies and certainly within the unionised sector through our unions.

 

     And we must also recognise that the alternative to being able to implement re-employment systematically would be a growing pool of financially strapped old citizens and that is something which is much worse for the individuals and for the countries as a whole.  And here, I would like to call attention to two observations.  Firstly, in recent days, we hear of media reports of green shoots of economic recovery in the US and then perhaps

Column: 488

globally.  This is more on the basis of the sudden exuberant stock market behaviour.  Whether this exuberance has a firm basis in the real economy or is irrational remains to be seen.  But we must not let this stalk of green shoots distract us from investing time and effort in the upgrading of our workers skills and employability because we are dealing with a structural issue and not a cyclical one.  

 

     The recovery, when it comes, will require Singapore companies to compete ever more fiercely with the survivors of the global shake-out.  These survivors are the fittest of the lot and the need for the Singaporean worker to be, not only job ready, but fighting fit, cannot be overstated.  Older workers would have to secure the employment through the value that they create at work just like everyone else.  They must actively improve their job worth and employment chances through upskilling.

 

     The second observation I would like to make here is, with regard to the ageing of the baby boomers and the first batch, that is those born in 1946, have just aged passed 62, which means to say that the rest of the boom are just coming through.  And that means that the number of workers reaching 62 will swell in the coming years before reaching a peak.  Companies will have to step up their efforts to design and match suitable jobs to their older workers in anticipation of the growing numbers of positions needed, year after year.

 

     The expected enactment of the Rule of Employment Law in 2012 will make this requirement mandatory.  And the choice facing companies is one of turning this requirement either into a value add or into a cost burden.

 

     With the enactment of the re-employment law getting closer each day, I hope that companies will make maximum effort to prepare themselves for

Column: 489

it and not leave it to the last moment or hope to arrive shipshape by muddling through.  I also hope that companies will not resort too ready to outplacement or to converting their ageing workers to contract service before retirement age as ways to side step the need. 

 

     I say this because I note that the percentage of our resident workforce that is on term contracts has continued to rise.  Between 2007 and 2008, it grew by 4.9% to 189,000 workers and now comprise 12.4% of the total resident workforce.  And on the subject of contract workers, I want to particularly speak about the situation faced by lower wage contract workers, and of the danger of facing them and that is of cheap sourcing and the impact of that on the economy as a whole and as well as on the earnings, employability and productivity of the workers.  Instead of being value conscious and productivity conscious, I think still too much emphasis is placed by too many companies on price consciousness alone.  And this has contributed partly to the decline in labour productivity.  Even if one takes into account the intentional move to kick down unemployment in this recession, the trend for labour productivity has still been adverse in recent quarters.  Now why is this so? 

 

     For a long time, the argument has been that, for the sake of economic competitiveness, cheaper labour is one way for companies to keep down the cost.  The upshot of this way of thinking is to bring in cheaper foreign labour and to outsource at lower rates.  There are two problems with this.  The first is the race-to-the-bottom challenge where cheap sourcing would tend to drive down the earnings, especially of lower wage workers.  Workfare payments go some way towards topping up the income of local lower wage workers and lowering the chances of their being sucked into the downward spiral, but only to a point.  The cheap sourcing mentality among buyers

Column: 490

and which fellow Member, Mr Zainudin, has elaborated earlier, gives rise to a lowest quote mentality among suppliers of goods and services and the ensuing cut-throat competition will press down wages over time. 

 

     The second problem with accepting this argument too readily is that there would be little motivation on the part of companies to think about raising competitiveness through raising productivity.  Water flows towards the lower level.  When there is a simpler solution for the immediate, then the important is sacrificed at the altar of the expedient and this will reap greater damage on the economy, even though short-term gains may be reaped.  To survive the downturn, we have indeed to cut cost and save jobs.  But, to prosper in the upturn, we cannot hope to be competitive just by being cheaper than others in our inputs, we must be more value-for-money and more productive than others.  And this means that we have to carefully consider the following:

 

     Firstly, that with outsourcing and contract service becoming ever more commonplace and with many companies pursuing these approaches as ways to save money and increase flexibility, how do we ensure that the growing pool of contract and freelance workers across different industries do not become less and less employable and more and more vulnerable to cheap sourcing?

 

     Many contract workers also work outside the boundaries of companies.  Their needs would increasingly have to be met beyond measures targeted at companies and this applies not only to lower wage workers, but also increasingly to PMETs who freelance or who are on contracts for service.  I want to underline this point that more solutions in the future would have to come from measures and arrangements that are not company-based.  This is because more and more

Column: 491

companies will operate using a mix of small internal core workforce and a larger flexible external or temporary workforce.  Therefore, productivity, professional development and individual employability cannot be achieved by addressing companies alone.  This also means that statistics and the interpretation of statistics would have to adapt as well because the share and scale of non-company-based data will increase over time. 

 

     Next, how do we ensure that companies and organisations in Singapore that embrace outsourcing are doing so smartly, in that they are pursuing productivity enhancement in outsourcing as a way to derive value-for-money, instead of being "penny wise, pound foolish"?  There are still sectors whose productivity levels have not improved much over the years and are also lacking the levels attained in other countries, and this is the nub of the problem. 

 

     NTUC's efforts in highlighting and countering cheap sourcing over the past few years have shown us how tough this problem is.  I think it transcends the question of business tactic.  It is a question of entrenched mindset that is very hard to dislodge and we have to find ways of cutting this Gordian knot so as to fundamentally transform our economy and the capability and worth of all in our workforce.  But one thing is for sure, regardless of the transformation path that we choose to take, the Singapore economy will always need migrant workers to help fuel it. 

 

     Today, foreigners constitute 37% of the workforce.  The number of foreign workers will grow in the recovery.  Migrant workers bring with them the numbers, skills and energy to complement and supplement our local workforce, and at a cost that companies find viable. 

Column: 492

While foreign talents should have less problems negotiating appropriate terms for themselves before accepting contracts, lower wage foreign workers are more prone to finding themselves at the receiving end of unequal arrangements. 

 

     More cases of such unfair, unsafe and unlawful practices have surfaced over the past months and reported in the media as the economy skidded and these are warning signs for us to take seriously.  We should proactively address questions of fair treatment, for example, prompt payment of the right wages, adequate health coverage, decent accommodation, safe transportation and enforce strictly against labour suppliers and employers who flout legislation and regulations.  Profits and greed cannot be allowed to override basic decency.  It does Singapore's reputation and attractiveness as a working location no good to be associated with shabby treatment of migrant workers. 

 

     I would also like to point out that if such workers are not perceived to be treated properly, source countries or provinces may have cause to ban their people from coming and, thereby, damaging our economic resilience.  Moreover, I believe that how employers choose to treat their foreign workers has a knock-on effect on how they treat local workers, especially those at the lower end of the economic ladder.  At the same time, as the number of foreign workers here grow, we must expect that there will be increasing tendency for them to organise amongst themselves to seek their own protection and rights as well as increased actions by groups to lobby on their behalf.  The more recent gatherings and group appeals at the MOM, as far as I am concerned, are not just a reflection of the downturn,  I think, they are indicative of a deeper trend of behavioural change. 

 

     We should hasten to do the necessary so as not to be misconstrued as being

Column: 493

passive or lax, instead, we should show ourselves to be decisive, proactive and enlightened in regulation.  As we focus our attention and efforts on tackling these and other emerging trends and work them to our advantage, we will strengthen ourselves against the competition while ensuring that Singapore coheres and continues to be one of best places on earth to work, live and play.  In this way, we will together build our home, our future and our Singapore. 

 

     Sir, I support the motion.
